        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1332924#c4">Comment 4<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 7, 2022, 7:31 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1332924#c4">Comment 4<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Jun 7, 2022, 7:31 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        This vulnerability should not exist in chrome. Microsoft believes that edgeupdate is in a restricted directory and cannot be hard linked through non-admin. <span class="line"><!---->This vulnerability should not exist in chrome. Microsoft believes that edgeupdate is in a restricted directory and cannot be hard linked through non-admin. <!----></span><br>In fact, hard links to external ".log" files affected by dacl vulnerabilities do not require bypassuac, unless the link target is in a restricted directory, and only through a directory like this (<span class="line"><!---->In fact, hard links to external ".log" files affected by dacl vulnerabilities do not require bypassuac, unless the link target is in a restricted directory, and only through a directory like this (<!----></span>https://github.com/sailay1996/CdpSvcLPE<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/sailay1996/CdpSvcLPE"><!---->https://github.com/sailay1996/CdpSvcLPE<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> that can be controlled by any user, dll hijacking can be completely constructed and exploited. You can check the "before" and "after" pictures in the package. Dacl vulnerabilities do exist.<span class="line"><!----> that can be controlled by any user, dll hijacking can be completely constructed and exploited. You can check the "before" and "after" pictures in the package. Dacl vulnerabilities do exist.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        Thanks for the heads-up @waffles.The MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log is an important part of Edge Updates diagnostic flow, so we'd like to keep logging to it if there ia a viable way of securing this log file<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the heads-up @waffles.The MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log is an important part of Edge Updates diagnostic flow, so we'd like to keep logging to it if there ia a viable way of securing this log file<!----></span><br>The thread mentions two different solutions to secure this file:<span class="line"><!---->The thread mentions two different solutions to secure this file:<!----></span><br>- oplocks <span class="line"><!---->- oplocks <!----></span><br>- DACLs<span class="line"><!---->- DACLs<!----></span><br>Can anyone elaborate on these approaches (e.g. how to use oplocks when MicoroftEdgeUpdate.log isn't running?, what DACL settings would secure this file?). On the surface, the DACL approach seems the most straightforward. And looking at the logging code [<span class="line"><!---->Can anyone elaborate on these approaches (e.g. how to use oplocks when MicoroftEdgeUpdate.log isn't running?, what DACL settings would secure this file?). On the surface, the DACL approach seems the most straightforward. And looking at the logging code [<!----></span>https://github.com/google/omaha/blob/main/omaha/base/logging.cc<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/google/omaha/blob/main/omaha/base/logging.cc"><!---->https://github.com/google/omaha/blob/main/omaha/base/logging.cc<!----></a>],<span class="line"><!---->],<!----></span> it seems the core issue is this:<span class="line"><!----> it seems the core issue is this:<!----></span><br><br>  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<span class="line"><!---->  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<!----></span><br>  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<span class="line"><!---->  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<!----></span><br>  CDacl dacl;<span class="line"><!---->  CDacl dacl;<!----></span><br>  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<!----></span><br>    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<span class="line"><!---->    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br><br>@sorin/@waffles -- is there a functionality reason that this is explicitly allowing all uses to *Write* and *Delete* the file? In most (all?) use cases systems install Omaha should be running as SYSTEM. And the file itself is size-limited, so I don't think disallow Delete would be a problem for end-users (e.g. to reclaim space).<span class="line"><!---->@sorin/@waffles -- is there a functionality reason that this is explicitly allowing all uses to *Write* and *Delete* the file? In most (all?) use cases systems install Omaha should be running as SYSTEM. And the file itself is size-limited, so I don't think disallow Delete would be a problem for end-users (e.g. to reclaim space).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1332924#c9">Comment 9<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Jun 8, 2022, 3:02 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1332924#c9">Comment 9<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Jun 8, 2022, 3:02 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        > Omaha can run as SYSTEM, or at medium for user installs as well as at medium for the system case before elevating. <span class="line"><!---->&gt; Omaha can run as SYSTEM, or at medium for user installs as well as at medium for the system case before elevating. <!----></span><br>Logging before we elevate is not a core scenario as we can do without (Edge is mostly in-box and always elevated). And on user installs log file is not created as SYSTEM (nor under C:\ProgramData) so I don't believe those uses are vulnerable.  <span class="line"><!---->Logging before we elevate is not a core scenario as we can do without (Edge is mostly in-box and always elevated). And on user installs log file is not created as SYSTEM (nor under C:\ProgramData) so I don't believe those uses are vulnerable.  <!----></span><br><br>So unless there isn't another reason why the "  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file." code is in place, I'm tempted to just remove that, assume the logging code won't blow up if it can't write.  Looks like I'll also need to fix up FileLogWriter::Initialize() to handle failures from CreateLoggingFile(), but not much else I can see.<span class="line"><!---->So unless there isn't another reason why the "  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file." code is in place, I'm tempted to just remove that, assume the logging code won't blow up if it can't write.  Looks like I'll also need to fix up FileLogWriter::Initialize() to handle failures from CreateLoggingFile(), but not much else I can see.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        Due to an issue with the monorail wizard workflow, this issue was not originally labeled as a security bug and, therefore, this issue did not make it to the security team bug queue for triage. This wizard workflow issue was just discovered today, so updating now accordingly. <span class="line"><!---->Due to an issue with the monorail wizard workflow, this issue was not originally labeled as a security bug and, therefore, this issue did not make it to the security team bug queue for triage. This wizard workflow issue was just discovered today, so updating now accordingly. <!----></span><br>cc'ing ajgo@ and wfh@ for a Chrome Windows SME perspective on this issue in particular.<span class="line"><!---->cc'ing ajgo@ and wfh@ for a Chrome Windows SME perspective on this issue in particular.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Confirmed.<span class="line"><!---->Confirmed.<!----></span><br><br>We are starting the flight of a new Edge Update series -- 1.3.165.xx -- that doesn't give all users read/write/delete access to the log file. This may lead to minor data loss  (e.g. logging of some EdgeUpdate activities) in some side cases, but we are willing to live with that to avoid this exploit.<span class="line"><!---->We are starting the flight of a new Edge Update series -- 1.3.165.xx -- that doesn't give all users read/write/delete access to the log file. This may lead to minor data loss  (e.g. logging of some EdgeUpdate activities) in some side cases, but we are willing to live with that to avoid this exploit.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        This has been fixed in Edge Update 1.3.165.21 (and later).<span class="line"><!---->This has been fixed in Edge Update 1.3.165.21 (and later).<!----></span><br><br>The code in FileLogWriter::CreateLoggingFile() [base\logging.cc] was changed to disable this code block:<span class="line"><!---->The code in FileLogWriter::CreateLoggingFile() [base\logging.cc] was changed to disable this code block:<!----></span><br><br>#if 0 // REMOVED due to Security issue: <span class="line"><!---->#if 0 // REMOVED due to Security issue: <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1332924#c8<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1332924#c8"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1332924#c8<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br>      // This will not allow for other non-elevated Omahas to write, but that<span class="line"><!---->      // This will not allow for other non-elevated Omahas to write, but that<!----></span><br>      // is in the minority case now that Edge is in-box.<span class="line"><!---->      // is in the minority case now that Edge is in-box.<!----></span><br>  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<span class="line"><!---->  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<!----></span><br>  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<span class="line"><!---->  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<!----></span><br>  CDacl dacl;<span class="line"><!---->  CDacl dacl;<!----></span><br>  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<!----></span><br>    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<span class="line"><!---->    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>#endif // 0<span class="line"><!---->#endif // 0<!----></span><br><br>This was a different mitigation than upstream--which disabled most logging--since logs are still important diagnostic tools for Edge Update and most installs are system-based (i.e., elevated).<span class="line"><!---->This was a different mitigation than upstream--which disabled most logging--since logs are still important diagnostic tools for Edge Update and most installs are system-based (i.e.,         by

        Hello, automated public disclosure of security bugs is 14 weeks after fix. Since this issue was just fixed on 6 September, that would not occur until 13 December. <span class="line"><!---->Hello, automated public disclosure of security bugs is 14 weeks after fix. Since this issue was just fixed on 6 September, that would not occur until 13 December. <!----></span><br>We have no insight into the mentioned email, but the MSRC team said they are working on this, so we would appreciate continued patience while Microsoft works to resolve this issue. <span class="line"><!---->We have no insight into the mentioned email, but the MSRC team said they are working on this, so we would appreciate continued patience while Microsoft works to resolve this issue. <!----></span><br>This is your finding, so of course, you are free to publicly disclose on your own, but I believe you would be ineligible for MSRC/Edge's bug bounty program and forfeit any reward from them. In the interim, in keeping with our Chromium public disclosure policies, this bug will remain restricted until the 13 December public disclosure date.<span class="line"><!---->This is your finding, so of course, you are free to publicly disclose on your own, but I believe you would be ineligible for MSRC/Edge's bug bounty program and forfeit any reward from them. In the interim, in keeping with our Chromium public disclosure policies, this bug will remain restricted until the 13 December public disclosure date.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      Steps to reproduce the problem:<b class="line"><!---->Steps to reproduce the problem:<!----></b><br>1.Just click the update button on msedge or restart your computer<span class="line"><!---->1.Just click the update button on msedge or restart your computer<!----></span><br>2.check demo1.mp4<span class="line"><!---->2.check demo1.mp4<!----></span><br>3.check demo2.mp4, exploit demo.mp4<span class="line"><!---->3.check demo2.mp4, exploit demo.mp4<!----></span><br><br>Problem Description:<b class="line"><!---->Problem Description:<!----></b><br>MicrosoftEdgeUpdate DACL Privilege Escalation<span class="line"><!---->MicrosoftEdgeUpdate DACL Privilege Escalation<!----></span><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br>Vulnerability reproduction environment:<span class="line"><!---->Vulnerability reproduction environment:<!----></span><br>win10 21h1 19043.1706<span class="line"><!---->win10 21h1 19043.1706<!----></span><br>Microsoft Edge 101.0.1210.39 (Official build) (64-bit)<span class="line"><!---->Microsoft Edge 101.0.1210.39 (Official build) (64-bit)<!----></span><br>Root Cause Analysis：<span class="line"><!---->Root Cause Analysis：<!----></span><br>There is a file called "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" under the directory "C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\", which can be deleted by any user with "del MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log"; we need to delete it first (not the point, you can choose not to delete it, it will not affect the vulnerability triggering ) to better observe the cause of the vulnerability:<span class="line"><!---->There is a file called "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" under the directory "C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\", which can be deleted by any user with "del MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log"; we need to delete it first (not the point, you can choose not to delete it, it will not affect the vulnerability triggering ) to better observe the cause of the vulnerability:<!----></span><br>When the msedge browser is updated, "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" will create the file "del MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" with system permissions, and then change the file acl through SetSecurityFile with system permissions, which will cause a dacl privilege escalation vulnerability(dacl permission override local privilege escalation vulnerability).  (Tag: you can view demo1.mp4)<span class="line"><!---->When the msedge browser is updated, "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" will create the file "del MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" with system permissions, and then change the file acl through SetSecurityFile with system permissions, which will cause a dacl privilege escalation vulnerability(dacl permission override local privilege escalation vulnerability).  (Tag: you can view demo1.mp4)<!----></span><br><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br>Vulnerability to reproduce:<span class="line"><!---->Vulnerability to reproduce:<!----></span><br>Note:If you are not admin user may need uac bypass to create hard link (CreateHardlink.exe), I have uac exploit also packaged in attachment to help you reproduce and understand this vulnerability on latest windows system and msedge browser.<span class="line"><!---->Note:If you are not admin user may need uac bypass to create hard link (CreateHardlink.exe), I have uac exploit also packaged in attachment to help you reproduce and understand this vulnerability on latest windows system and msedge browser.<!----></span><br><br>1. First you need to create a hard link from the log file to any target file you wish to be exploited by this lpe exploit (I used the hosts file as a demonstration), "CreateHardlink.exe C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\MicrosoftEdgeUpdate. log "C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts"", you can first "del C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" before this step, but this step does not affect;<span class="line"><!---->1. First you need to create a hard link from the log file to any target file you wish to be exploited by this lpe exploit (I used the hosts file as a demonstration), "CreateHardlink.exe C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\MicrosoftEdgeUpdate. log "C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts"", you can first "del C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" before this step, but this step does not affect;<!----></span><br><br><br>2. Open the msedge browser, it will automatically update when it is restarted, but in order to trigger the vulnerability faster, we can manually click the update button to trigger "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" to help us execute the dacl lpe attack;<span class="line"><!---->2. Open the msedge browser, it will automatically update when it is restarted, but in order to trigger the vulnerability faster, we can manually click the update button to trigger "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" to help us execute the dacl lpe attack;<!----></span><br><br>3. When the update is completed, we can see that the acl permissions of the hosts file have been changed by "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" with system permissions. So far, this dacl lpe vulnerability has completed everything. (Tag: you can view demo2.mp4)<span class="line"><!---->3. When the update is completed, we can see that the acl permissions of the hosts file have been changed by "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" with system permissions. So far, this dacl lpe vulnerability has completed everything. (Tag: you can view demo2.mp4)<!----></span><br><br><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br>Vulnerability impact:<span class="line"><!---->Vulnerability impact:<!----></span><br>I think this DACL Permissions Overwrite Privilege Escalation vulnerability should affect the latest version of MSEdge browser and any latest version of windows system (including windows 11).<span class="line"><!---->I think this DACL Permissions Overwrite Privilege Escalation vulnerability should affect the latest version of MSEdge browser and any latest version of windows system (including windows 11).<!----></span><br><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br>Repair suggestion:<span class="line"><!---->Repair suggestion:<!----></span><br>A simple solution is to set a file oplock on the file, so when the user SetOpLock opens the file, the oplock fires, you'll know that some action was performed on the file, and then you can release the lock and do your thing.<span class="line"><!---->A simple solution is to set a file oplock on the file, so when the user SetOpLock opens the file, the oplock fires, you'll know that some action was performed on the file, and then you can release the lock and do your thing.<!----></span><br><br>Additional Comments:<b class="line"><!---->Additional Comments:<!----></b><br>https://drive.google.com/file/d/1lf1qLovXBdLXbYvPKZBg4qYeJ6_CAiau/view?usp=sharing<a class="undefined" target="_blank" class="line"><!---->"writeup(pass=1)"<!----></span><br><br>Chrome version: <b class="line"><!---->Chrome version: <!----></b>102.0.5005.63 <span class="line"><!---->102.0.5005.63 <!----></span>Channel: <b class="line"><!---->Channel: <!----></b>Stable<span class="line"><!---->Stable<!----></span><br><br>OS:<b class="line"><!---->OS:<!----></b>Windows<span         Chrome should be protected from this:<span class="line"><!---->Chrome should be protected from this:<!----></span><br>```<span class="line"><!---->```<!----></span><br>cl/394570412<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://cl/394570412"><!---->cl/394570412<!----></a> and crbug/1245879: Security: Incomplete fix for CVE-2021-30577: Logging to files has been a continuing security issue for us. For that reason, logging to file is now only possible by setting an UpdateDev REG_DWORD value "IsEnabledLogToFile" to 1.         This vulnerability should not exist in chrome. Microsoft believes that edgeupdate is in a restricted directory and cannot be hard linked through non-admin. <span class="line"><!---->This vulnerability should not exist in chrome. Microsoft believes that edgeupdate is in a restricted directory and cannot be hard linked through non-admin. <!----></span><br>In fact, hard links to external ".log" files affected by dacl vulnerabilities do not require bypassuac, unless the link target is in a restricted directory, and only through a directory like this (<span class="line"><!---->In fact, hard links to external ".log" files affected by dacl vulnerabilities do not require bypassuac, unless the link target is in a restricted directory, and only through a directory like this (<!----></span>https://github.com/sailay1996/CdpSvcLPE<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/sailay1996/CdpSvcLPE"><!---->https://github.com/sailay1996/CdpSvcLPE<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> that can be controlled by any user, dll hijacking can be completely constructed and exploited. You can check the "before" and "after" pictures in the package. Dacl vulnerabilities do exist.<span class="line"><!----> that can be controlled by any user, dll hijacking can be completely constructed and exploited. You can check the "before" and "after" pictures in the package. Dacl vulnerabilities do exist.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        If look at brave browsers, I have previously reported to brave that the same browser update caused dacl vulnerabilities, and the fix they made was to add "dacl protection", like the one in the picture.<span class="line"><!---->If look at brave browsers, I have previously reported to brave that the same browser update caused dacl vulnerabilities, and the fix they made was to add "dacl protection", like the one in the picture.<!----></span><br>brave browser.png<span class="line"><!---->brave browser.png<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the heads-up @waffles.The MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log is an important part of Edge Updates diagnostic flow, so we'd like to keep logging to it if there ia a viable way of securing this log file<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the heads-up @waffles.The MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log is an important part of Edge Updates diagnostic flow, so we'd like to keep logging to it if there ia a viable way of securing this log file<!----></span><br>The thread mentions two different solutions to secure this file:<span class="line"><!---->The thread mentions two different solutions to secure this file:<!----></span><br>- oplocks <span class="line"><!---->- oplocks <!----></span><br>- DACLs<span class="line"><!---->- DACLs<!----></span><br>Can anyone elaborate on these approaches (e.g. how to use oplocks when MicoroftEdgeUpdate.log isn't running?, what DACL settings would secure this file?). On the surface, the DACL approach seems the most straightforward. And looking at the logging code [<span class="line"><!---->Can anyone elaborate on these approaches (e.g. how to use oplocks when MicoroftEdgeUpdate.log isn't running?, what DACL settings would secure this file?). On the surface, the DACL approach seems the most straightforward. And looking at the logging code [<!----></span>https://github.com/google/omaha/blob/main/omaha/base/logging.cc<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/google/omaha/blob/main/omaha/base/logging.cc"><!---->https://github.com/google/omaha/blob/main/omaha/base/logging.cc<!----></a>],<span class="line"><!---->],<!----></span> it seems the core issue is this:<span class="line"><!----> it seems the core issue is this:<!----></span><br><br>  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<span class="line"><!---->  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<!----></span><br>  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<span class="line"><!---->  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<!----></span><br>  CDacl dacl;<span class="line"><!---->  CDacl dacl;<!----></span><br>  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<!----></span><br>    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<span class="line"><!---->    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br><br>@sorin/@waffles -- is there a functionality reason that this is explicitly allowing all uses to *Write* and *Delete* the file? In most (all?) use cases systems install Omaha should be running as SYSTEM. And the file itself is size-limited, so I don't think disallow Delete would be a problem for end-users (e.g. to reclaim space).<span class="line"><!---->@sorin/@waffles -- is there a functionality reason that this is explicitly allowing all uses to *Write* and *Delete* the file? In most (all?) use cases systems install Omaha should be running as SYSTEM. And the file itself is size-limited, so I don't think disallow Delete would be a problem for end-users (e.g. to reclaim space).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        > Omaha can run as SYSTEM, or at medium for user installs as well as at medium for the system case before elevating. <span class="line"><!---->&gt; Omaha can run as SYSTEM, or at medium for user installs as well as at medium for the system case before elevating. <!----></span><br>Logging before we elevate is not a core scenario as we can do without (Edge is mostly in-box and always elevated). And on user installs log file is not created as SYSTEM (nor under C:\ProgramData) so I don't believe those uses are vulnerable.  <span class="line"><!---->Logging before we elevate is not a core scenario as we can do without (Edge is mostly in-box and always elevated). And on user installs log file is not created as SYSTEM (nor under C:\ProgramData) so I don't believe those uses are vulnerable.  <!----></span><br><br>So unless there isn't another reason why the "  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file." code is in place, I'm tempted to just remove that, assume the logging code won't blow up if it can't write.  Looks like I'll also need to fix up FileLogWriter::Initialize() to handle failures from CreateLoggingFile(), but not much else I can see.<span class="line"><!---->So unless there isn't another reason why the "  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file." code is in place, I'm tempted to just remove that, assume the logging code won't blow up if it can't write.  Looks like I'll also need to fix up FileLogWriter::Initialize() to handle failures from CreateLoggingFile(), but not much else I can see.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Due to an issue with the monorail wizard workflow, this issue was not originally labeled as a security bug and, therefore, this issue did not make it to the security team bug queue for triage. This wizard workflow issue was just discovered today, so updating now accordingly. <span class="line"><!---->Due to an issue with the monorail wizard workflow, this issue was not originally labeled as a security bug and, therefore, this issue did not make it to the security team bug queue for triage. This wizard workflow issue was just discovered today, so updating now accordingly. <!----></span><br>cc'ing ajgo@ and wfh@ for a Chrome Windows SME perspective on this issue in particular.<span class="line"><!---->cc'ing ajgo@ and wfh@ for a Chrome Windows SME perspective on this issue in particular.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Confirmed.<span class="line"><!---->Confirmed.<!----></span><br><br>We are starting the flight of a new Edge Update series -- 1.3.165.xx -- that doesn't give all users read/write/delete access to the log file. This may lead to minor data loss  (e.g. logging of some EdgeUpdate activities) in some side cases, but we are willing to live with that to avoid this exploit.<span class="line"><!---->We are starting the flight of a new Edge Update series -- 1.3.165.xx -- that doesn't give all users read/write/delete access to the log file. This may lead to minor data loss  (e.g. logging of some EdgeUpdate activities) in some side cases, but we are willing to live with that to avoid this exploit.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1332924#c22">Comment 22<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Sep 6, 2022, 2:01 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        This has been fixed in Edge Update 1.3.165.21 (and later).<span class="line"><!---->This has been fixed in Edge Update 1.3.165.21 (and later).<!----></span><br><br>The code in FileLogWriter::CreateLoggingFile() [base\logging.cc] was changed to disable this code block:<span class="line"><!---->The code in FileLogWriter::CreateLoggingFile() [base\logging.cc] was changed to disable this code block:<!----></span><br><br>#if 0 // REMOVED due to Security issue: <span class="line"><!---->#if 0 // REMOVED due to Security issue: <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1332924#c8<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1332924#c8"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1332924#c8<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br>      // This will not allow for other non-elevated Omahas to write, but that<span class="line"><!---->      // This will not allow for other non-elevated Omahas to write, but that<!----></span><br>      // is in the minority case now that Edge is in-box.<span class="line"><!---->      // is in the minority case now that Edge is in-box.<!----></span><br>  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<span class="line"><!---->  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<!----></span><br>  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<span class="line"><!---->  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<!----></span><br>  CDacl dacl;<span class="line"><!---->  CDacl dacl;<!----></span><br>  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<!----></span><br>    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<span class="line"><!---->    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>#endif // 0<span class="line"><!---->#endif // 0<!----></span><br><br>This was a different mitigation than upstream--which disabled most logging--since logs are still important diagnostic tools for Edge Update and most installs are system-based (i.e., elevated).<span class="line"><!---->This was a different mitigation than upstream--which disabled most logging--since logs are still important diagnostic tools for Edge Update and most installs are system-based (i.e., elevated).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Hello, automated public disclosure of security bugs is 14 weeks after fix. Since this issue was just fixed on 6 September, that would not occur until 13 December. <span class="line"><!---->Hello, automated public disclosure of security bugs is 14 weeks after fix. Since this issue was just fixed on 6 September, that would not occur until 13 December. <!----></span><br>We have no insight into the mentioned email, but the MSRC team said they are working on this, so we would appreciate continued patience while Microsoft works to resolve this issue. <span class="line"><!---->We have no insight into the mentioned email, but the MSRC team said they are working on this, so we would appreciate continued patience while Microsoft works to resolve this issue. <!----></span><br>This is your finding, so of course, you are free to publicly disclose on your own, but I believe you would be ineligible for MSRC/Edge's bug bounty program and forfeit any reward from them. In the interim, in keeping with our Chromium public disclosure policies, this bug will remain restricted until the 13 December public disclosure date.<span class="line"><!---->This is your finding, so of course, you are free to publicly disclose on your own, but I believe you would be ineligible for MSRC/Edge's bug bounty program and forfeit any reward from them. In the interim, in keeping with our Chromium public disclosure policies, this bug will remain restricted until the 13 December public disclosure date.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      Steps to reproduce the problem:<b class="line"><!---->Steps to reproduce the problem:<!----></b><br>1.Just click the update button on msedge or restart your computer<span class="line"><!---->1.Just click the update button on msedge or restart your computer<!----></span><br>2.check demo1.mp4<span class="line"><!---->2.check demo1.mp4<!----></span><br>3.check demo2.mp4, exploit demo.mp4<span class="line"><!---->3.check demo2.mp4, exploit demo.mp4<!----></span><br><br>Problem Description:<b class="line"><!---->Problem Description:<!----></b><br>MicrosoftEdgeUpdate DACL Privilege Escalation<span class="line"><!---->MicrosoftEdgeUpdate DACL Privilege Escalation<!----></span><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br>Vulnerability reproduction environment:<span class="line"><!---->Vulnerability reproduction environment:<!----></span><br>win10 21h1 19043.1706<span class="line"><!---->win10 21h1 19043.1706<!----></span><br>Microsoft Edge 101.0.1210.39 (Official build) (64-bit)<span class="line"><!---->Microsoft Edge 101.0.1210.39 (Official build) (64-bit)<!----></span><br>Root Cause Analysis：<span class="line"><!---->Root Cause Analysis：<!----></span><br>There is a file called "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" under the directory "C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\", which can be deleted by any user with "del MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log"; we need to delete it first (not the point, you can choose not to delete it, it will not affect the vulnerability triggering ) to better observe the cause of the vulnerability:<span class="line"><!---->There is a file called "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" under the directory "C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\", which can be deleted by any user with "del MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log"; we need to delete it first (not the point, you can choose not to delete it, it will not affect the vulnerability triggering ) to better observe the cause of the vulnerability:<!----></span><br>When the msedge browser is updated, "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" will create the file "del MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" with system permissions, and then change the file acl through SetSecurityFile with system permissions, which will cause a dacl privilege escalation vulnerability(dacl permission override local privilege escalation vulnerability).  (Tag: you can view demo1.mp4)<span class="line"><!---->When the msedge browser is updated, "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" will create the file "del MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" with system permissions, and then change the file acl through SetSecurityFile with system permissions, which will cause a dacl privilege escalation vulnerability(dacl permission override local privilege escalation vulnerability).  (Tag: you can view demo1.mp4)<!----></span><br><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br>Vulnerability to reproduce:<span class="line"><!---->Vulnerability to reproduce:<!----></span><br>Note:If you are not admin user may need uac bypass to create hard link (CreateHardlink.exe), I have uac exploit also packaged in attachment to help you reproduce and understand this vulnerability on latest windows system and msedge browser.<span class="line"><!---->Note:If you are not admin user may need uac bypass to create hard link (CreateHardlink.exe), I have uac exploit also packaged in attachment to help you reproduce and understand this vulnerability on latest windows system and msedge browser.<!----></span><br><br>1. First you need to create a hard link from the log file to any target file you wish to be exploited by this lpe exploit (I used the hosts file as a demonstration), "CreateHardlink.exe C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\MicrosoftEdgeUpdate. log "C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts"", you can first "del C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" before this step, but this step does not affect;<span class="line"><!---->1. First you need to create a hard link from the log file to any target file you wish to be exploited by this lpe exploit (I used the hosts file as a demonstration), "CreateHardlink.exe C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\MicrosoftEdgeUpdate. log "C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts"", you can first "del C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" before this step, but this step does not affect;<!----></span><br><br><br>2. Open the msedge browser, it will automatically update when it is restarted, but in order to trigger the vulnerability faster, we can manually click the update button to trigger "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" to help us execute the dacl lpe attack;<span class="line"><!---->2. Open the msedge browser, it will automatically update when it is restarted, but in order to trigger the vulnerability faster, we can manually click the update button to trigger "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" to help us execute the dacl lpe attack;<!----></span><br><br>3. When the update is completed, we can see that the acl permissions of the hosts file have been changed by "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" with system permissions. So far, this dacl lpe vulnerability has completed everything. (Tag: you can view demo2.mp4)<span class="line"><!---->3. When the update is completed, we can see that the acl permissions of the hosts file have been changed by "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" with system permissions. So far, this dacl lpe vulnerability has completed everything. (Tag: you can view demo2.mp4)<!----></span><br><br><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br>Vulnerability impact:<span class="line"><!---->Vulnerability impact:<!----></span><br>I think this DACL Permissions Overwrite Privilege Escalation vulnerability should affect the latest version of MSEdge browser and any latest version of windows system (including windows 11).<span class="line"><!---->I think this DACL Permissions Overwrite Privilege Escalation vulnerability should affect the latest version of MSEdge browser and any latest version of windows system (including windows 11).<!----></span><br><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br>Repair suggestion:<span class="line"><!---->Repair suggestion:<!----></span><br>A simple solution is to set a file oplock on the file, so when the user SetOpLock opens the file, the oplock fires, you'll know that some action was performed on the file, and then you can release the lock and do your thing.<span class="line"><!---->A simple solution is to set a file oplock on the file, so when the user SetOpLock opens the file, the oplock fires, you'll know that some action was performed on the file, and then you can release the lock and do your thing.<!----></span><br><br>Additional Comments:<b class="line"><!---->Additional Comments:<!----></b><br>https://drive.google.com/file/d/1lf1qLovXBdLXbYvPKZBg4qYeJ6_CAiau/view?usp=sharing<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1lf1qLovXBdLXbYvPKZBg4qYeJ6_CAiau/view?usp=sharing"><!---->https://drive.google.com/file/d/1lf1qLovXBdLXbYvPKZBg4qYeJ6_CAiau/view?usp=sharing<!----></a><br><br>"writeup(pass=1)"<span class="line"><!---->"writeup(pass=1)"<!----></span><br><br>Chrome version: <b class="line"><!---->Chrome version: <!----></b>102.0.5005.63 <span class="line"><!---->102.0.5005.63 <!----></span>Channel: <b class="line"><!---->Channel: <!----></b>Stable<span class="line"><!---->Stable<!----></span><br><br>OS:<b class="line"><!---->OS:<!----></b>Windows<span class="line"><!---->Windows<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I'm not sure attacks that require admin / uac bypass are within the threat model in the first place, but the security team can comment on that better than I can.<span class="line"><!---->I'm not sure attacks that require admin / uac bypass are within the threat model in the first place, but the security team can comment on that better than I can.<!----></span><br><br>I know that we have somewhat recently changed logging in Omaha 3 to deal with similar kinds of log file problems, Ganesh & Sorin, can you answer whether Omaha might still behave similarly to Edge in this case?<span class="line"><!---->I know that we have somewhat recently changed logging in Omaha 3 to deal with similar kinds of log file problems, Ganesh &amp; Sorin, can you answer whether Omaha might still behave similarly to Edge in this case?<!----></span><br><br>Dave, does it make sense for me to cc the relevant folks from Microsoft? I agree that if Chrome/Omaha is not affected it belongs in the Edge tracker, but my thinking is that it is harmless to cc them for context / as a courtesy.<span class="line"><!---->Dave, does it make sense for me to cc the relevant folks from Microsoft?           Comment 3<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1332924#c3">Comment 3<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

        This vulnerability should not exist in chrome. Microsoft believes that edgeupdate is in a restricted directory and cannot be hard linked through non-admin. <span class="line"><!---->This vulnerability should not exist in chrome. Microsoft believes that edgeupdate is in a restricted directory and cannot be hard linked through non-admin. <!----></span><br>In fact, hard links to external ".log" files affected by dacl vulnerabilities do not require bypassuac, unless the link target is in a restricted directory, and only through a directory like this (<span class="line"><!---->In fact, hard links to external ".log" files affected by dacl vulnerabilities do not require bypassuac, unless the link target is in a restricted directory, and only through a directory like this (<!----></span>https://github.com/sailay1996/CdpSvcLPE<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/sailay1996/CdpSvcLPE"><!---->https://github.com/sailay1996/CdpSvcLPE<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> that can be controlled by any user, dll hijacking can be completely constructed and exploited. You can check the "before" and "after" pictures in the package. Dacl vulnerabilities do exist.<span class="line"><!----> that can be controlled by any user, dll hijacking can be completely constructed and exploited. You can check the "before" and "after" pictures in the package. Dacl vulnerabilities do exist.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the heads-up @waffles.The MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log is an important part of Edge Updates diagnostic flow, so we'd like to keep logging to it if there ia a viable way of securing this log file<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the heads-up @waffles.The MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log is an important part of Edge Updates diagnostic flow, so we'd like to keep logging to it if there ia a viable way of securing this log file<!----></span><br>The thread mentions two different solutions to secure this file:<span class="line"><!---->The thread mentions two different solutions to secure this file:<!----></span><br>- oplocks <span class="line"><!---->- oplocks <!----></span><br>- DACLs<span class="line"><!---->- DACLs<!----></span><br>Can anyone elaborate on these approaches (e.g. how to use oplocks when MicoroftEdgeUpdate.log isn't running?, what DACL settings would secure this file?). On the surface, the DACL approach seems the most straightforward. And looking at the logging code [<span class="line"><!---->Can anyone elaborate on these approaches (e.g. how to use oplocks when MicoroftEdgeUpdate.log isn't running?, what DACL settings would secure this file?). On the surface, the DACL approach seems the most straightforward. And looking at the logging code [<!----></span>https://github.com/google/omaha/blob/main/omaha/base/logging.cc<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/google/omaha/blob/main/omaha/base/logging.cc"><!---->https://github.com/google/omaha/blob/main/omaha/base/logging.cc<!----></a>],<span class="line"><!---->],<!----></span> it seems the core issue is this:<span class="line"><!----> it seems the core issue is this:<!----></span><br><br>  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<span class="line"><!---->  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<!----></span><br>  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<span class="line"><!---->  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<!----></span><br>  CDacl dacl;<span class="line"><!---->  CDacl dacl;<!----></span><br>  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<!----></span><br>    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<span class="line"><!---->    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br><br>@sorin/@waffles -- is there a functionality reason that this is explicitly allowing all uses to *Write* and *Delete* the file? In most (all?) use cases systems install Omaha should be running as SYSTEM. And the file itself is size-limited, so I don't think disallow Delete would be a problem for end-users (e.g. to reclaim space).<span class="line"><!---->@sorin/@waffles -- is there a functionality reason that this is explicitly allowing all uses to *Write* and *Delete* the file? In most (all?) use cases systems install Omaha should be running as SYSTEM. And the file itself is size-limited, so I don't think disallow Delete would be a problem for end-users (e.g. to reclaim space).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1332924#c9">Comment 9<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Jun 8, 2022, 3:02 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        > Omaha can run as SYSTEM, or at medium for user installs as well as at medium for the system case before elevating. <span class="line"><!---->&gt; Omaha can run as SYSTEM, or at medium for user installs as well as at medium for the system case before elevating. <!----></span><br>Logging before we elevate is not a core scenario as we can do without (Edge is mostly in-box and always elevated). And on user installs log file is not created as SYSTEM (nor under C:\ProgramData) so I don't believe those uses are vulnerable.  <span class="line"><!---->Logging before we elevate is not a core scenario as we can do without (Edge is mostly in-box and always elevated). And on user installs log file is not created as SYSTEM (nor under C:\ProgramData) so I don't believe those uses are vulnerable.  <!----></span><br><br>So unless there isn't another reason why the "  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file." code is in place, I'm tempted to just remove that, assume the logging code won't blow up if it can't write.  Looks like I'll also need to fix up FileLogWriter::Initialize() to handle failures from CreateLoggingFile(), but not much else I can see.<span class="line"><!---->So unless there isn't another reason why the "  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file." code is in place, I'm tempted to just remove that, assume the logging code won't blow up if it can't write.  Looks like I'll also need to fix up FileLogWriter::Initialize() to handle failures from CreateLoggingFile(), but not much else I can see.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Due to an issue with the monorail wizard workflow, this issue was not originally labeled as a security bug and, therefore, this issue did not make it to the security team bug queue for triage. This wizard workflow issue was just discovered today, so updating now accordingly. <span class="line"><!---->Due to an issue with the monorail wizard workflow, this issue was not originally labeled as a security bug and, therefore, this issue did not make it to the security team bug queue for triage.         Confirmed.<span class="line"><!---->Confirmed.<!----></span><br><br>We are starting the flight of a new Edge Update series -- 1.3.165.xx -- that doesn't give all users read/write/delete access to the log file. This may lead to minor data loss  (e.g. logging of some EdgeUpdate activities) in some side cases, but we are willing to live with that to avoid this exploit.<span class="line"><!---->We are starting the flight of a new Edge Update series -- 1.3.165.xx -- that doesn't give all users read/write/delete access to the log file. This may lead to minor data loss  (e.g. logging of some EdgeUpdate activities) in some side cases, but we are willing to live with that to avoid this exploit.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        This has been fixed in Edge Update 1.3.165.21 (and later).<span class="line"><!---->This has been fixed in Edge Update 1.3.165.21 (and later).<!----></span><br><br>The code in FileLogWriter::CreateLoggingFile() [base\logging.cc] was changed to disable this code block:<span class="line"><!---->The code in FileLogWriter::CreateLoggingFile() [base\logging.cc] was changed to disable this code block:<!----></span><br><br>#if 0 // REMOVED due to Security issue: <span class="line"><!---->#if 0 // REMOVED due to Security issue: <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1332924#c8<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1332924#c8"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1332924#c8<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br>      // This will not allow for other non-elevated Omahas to write, but that<span class="line"><!---->      // This will not allow for other non-elevated Omahas to write, but that<!----></span><br>      // is in the minority case now that Edge is in-box.<span class="line"><!---->      // is in the minority case now that Edge is in-box.<!----></span><br>  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<span class="line"><!---->  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<!----></span><br>  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<span class="line"><!---->  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<!----></span><br>  CDacl dacl;<span class="line"><!---->  CDacl dacl;<!----></span><br>  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<!----></span><br>    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<span class="line"><!---->    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>#endif // 0<span class="line"><!---->#endif // 0<!----></span><br><br>This was a different mitigation than upstream--which disabled most logging--since logs are still important diagnostic tools for Edge Update and most installs are system-based (i.e., elevated).<span class="line"><!---->This was a different mitigation than upstream--which disabled most logging--since logs are still important diagnostic tools for Edge Update and most installs are system-based (i.e., elevated).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Hello, automated public disclosure of security bugs is 14 weeks after fix. Since this issue was just fixed on 6 September, that would not occur until 13 December. <span class="line"><!---->Hello, automated public disclosure of security bugs is 14 weeks after fix. Since this issue was just fixed on 6 September, that would not occur until 13 December. <!----></span><br>We have no insight into the mentioned email, but the MSRC team said they are working on this, so we would appreciate continued patience while Microsoft works to resolve this issue. <span class="line"><!---->We have no insight into the mentioned email, but the MSRC team said they are working on this, so we would appreciate continued patience while Microsoft works to resolve this issue. <!----></span><br>This is your finding, so of course, you are free to publicly disclose on your own, but I believe you would be ineligible for MSRC/Edge's bug bounty program and forfeit any reward from them. In the interim, in keeping with our Chromium public disclosure policies, this bug will remain restricted until the 13 December public disclosure date.<span class="line"><!---->This is your finding, so of course, you are free to publicly disclose on your own, but I believe you would be ineligible for MSRC/Edge's bug bounty program and forfeit any reward from them.       Steps to reproduce the problem:<b class="line"><!---->Steps to reproduce the problem:<!----></b><br>1.Just click the update button on msedge or restart your computer<span class="line"><!---->1.Just click the update button on msedge or restart your computer<!----></span><br>2.check demo1.mp4<span class="line"><!---->2.check demo1.mp4<!----></span><br>3.check demo2.mp4, exploit demo.mp4<span class="line"><!---->3.check demo2.mp4, exploit demo.mp4<!----></span><br><br>Problem Description:<b class="line"><!---->Problem Description:<!----></b><br>MicrosoftEdgeUpdate DACL Privilege Escalation<span class="line"><!---->MicrosoftEdgeUpdate DACL Privilege Escalation<!----></span><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br>Vulnerability reproduction environment:<span class="line"><!---->Vulnerability reproduction environment:<!----></span><br>win10 21h1 19043.1706<span class="line"><!---->win10 21h1 19043.1706<!----></span><br>Microsoft Edge 101.0.1210.39 (Official build) (64-bit)<span class="line"><!---->Microsoft Edge 101.0.1210.39 (Official build) (64-bit)<!----></span><br>Root Cause Analysis：<span class="line"><!---->Root Cause Analysis：<!----></span><br>There is a file called "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" under the directory "C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\", which can be deleted by any user with "del MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log"; we need to delete it first (not the point, you can choose not to delete it, it will not affect the vulnerability triggering ) to better observe the cause of the vulnerability:<span class="line"><!---->There is a file called "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" under the directory "C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\", which can be deleted by any user with "del MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log"; we need to delete it first (not the point, you can choose not to delete it, it will not affect the vulnerability triggering ) to better observe the cause of the vulnerability:<!----></span><br>When the msedge browser is updated, "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" will create the file "del MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" with system permissions, and then change the file acl through SetSecurityFile with system permissions, which will cause a dacl privilege escalation vulnerability(dacl permission override local privilege escalation vulnerability).  (Tag: you can view demo1.mp4)<span class="line"><!---->When the msedge browser is updated, "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" will create the file "del MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" with system permissions, and then change the file acl through SetSecurityFile with system permissions, which will cause a dacl privilege escalation vulnerability(dacl permission override local privilege escalation vulnerability).  (Tag: you can view demo1.mp4)<!----></span><br><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br>Vulnerability to reproduce:<span class="line"><!---->Vulnerability to reproduce:<!----></span><br>Note:If you are not admin user may need uac bypass to create hard link (CreateHardlink.exe), I have uac exploit also packaged in attachment to help you reproduce and understand this vulnerability on latest windows system and msedge browser.<span class="line"><!---->Note:If you are not admin user may need uac bypass to create hard link (CreateHardlink.exe), I have uac exploit also packaged in attachment to help you reproduce and understand this vulnerability on latest windows system and msedge browser.<!----></span><br><br>1. First you need to create a hard link from the log file to any target file you wish to be exploited by this lpe exploit (I used the hosts file as a demonstration), "CreateHardlink.exe C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\MicrosoftEdgeUpdate. log "C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts"", you can first "del C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" before this step, but this step does not affect;<span class="line"><!---->1. First you need to create a hard link from the log file to any target file you wish to be exploited by this lpe exploit (I used the hosts file as a demonstration), "CreateHardlink.exe C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\MicrosoftEdgeUpdate. log "C:\Windows\System32\drivers\etc\hosts"", you can first "del C:\ProgramData\Microsoft\EdgeUpdate\Log\MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log" before this step, but this step does not affect;<!----></span><br><br><br>2. Open the msedge browser, it will automatically update when it is restarted, but in order to trigger the vulnerability faster, we can manually click the update button to trigger "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" to help us execute the dacl lpe attack;<span class="line"><!---->2. Open the msedge browser, it will automatically update when it is restarted, but in order to trigger the vulnerability faster, we can manually click the update button to trigger "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" to help us execute the dacl lpe attack;<!----></span><br><br>3. When the update is completed, we can see that the acl permissions of the hosts file have been changed by "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" with system permissions. So far, this dacl lpe vulnerability has completed everything. (Tag: you can view demo2.mp4)<span class="line"><!---->3. When the update is completed, we can see that the acl permissions of the hosts file have been changed by "MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.exe" with system permissions. So far, this dacl lpe vulnerability has completed everything. (Tag: you can view demo2.mp4)<!----></span><br><br><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br>Vulnerability impact:<span class="line"><!---->Vulnerability impact:<!----></span><br>I think this DACL Permissions Overwrite Privilege Escalation vulnerability should affect the latest version of MSEdge browser and any latest version of windows system (including windows 11).<span class="line"><!---->I think this DACL Permissions Overwrite Privilege Escalation vulnerability should affect the latest version of MSEdge browser and any latest version of windows system (including windows 11).<!----></span><br><br>------------------------------------------------------------------------<span class="line"><!---->------------------------------------------------------------------------<!----></span><br>Repair suggestion:<span class="line"><!---->Repair suggestion:<!----></span><br>A simple solution is to set a file oplock on the file, so when the user SetOpLock opens the file, the oplock fires, you'll know that some action was performed on the file, and then you can release the lock and do your thing.<span class="line"><!---->A simple solution is to set a file oplock on the file, so when the user SetOpLock opens the file, the oplock fires, you'll know that some action was performed on the file, and then you can release the lock and do your thing.<!----></span><br><br>Additional Comments:<b class="line"><!---->Additional Comments:<!----></b><br>https://drive.google.com/file/d/1lf1qLovXBdLXbYvPKZBg4qYeJ6_CAiau/view?usp=sharing<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://drive.google.com/file/d/1lf1qLovXBdLXbYvPKZBg4qYeJ6_CAiau/view?usp=sharing"><!---->https://drive.google.com/file/d/1lf1qLovXBdLXbYvPKZBg4qYeJ6_CAiau/view?usp=sharing<!----></a><br><br>"writeup(pass=1)"<span class="line"><!---->"writeup(pass=1)"<!----></span><br><br>Chrome version: <b class="line"><!---->Chrome version: <!----></b>102.0.5005.63 <span class="line"><!---->102.0.5005.63 <!----></span>Channel: <b class="line"><!---->Channel: <!----></b>Stable<span class="line"><!---->Stable<!----></span><br><br>OS:<b class="line"><!---->OS:<!----></b>Windows<span class="line"><!---->Windows<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

For that reason, logging to file is now only possible by setting an UpdateDev REG_DWORD value "IsEnabledLogToFile" to 1.         This vulnerability should not exist in chrome. Microsoft believes that edgeupdate is in a restricted directory and cannot be hard linked through non-admin. <span class="line"><!---->This vulnerability should not exist in chrome. Microsoft believes that edgeupdate is in a restricted directory and cannot be hard linked through non-admin. <!----></span><br>In fact, hard links to external ".log" files affected by dacl vulnerabilities do not require bypassuac, unless the link target is in a restricted directory, and only through a directory like this (<span class="line"><!---->In fact, hard links to external ".log" files affected by dacl vulnerabilities do not require bypassuac, unless the link target is in a restricted directory, and only through a directory like this (<!----></span>https://github.com/sailay1996/CdpSvcLPE<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/sailay1996/CdpSvcLPE"><!---->https://github.com/sailay1996/CdpSvcLPE<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span> that can be controlled by any user, dll hijacking can be completely constructed and exploited. You can check the "before" and "after" pictures in the package. Dacl vulnerabilities do exist.<span class="line"><!----> that can be controlled by any user, dll hijacking can be completely constructed and exploited.         Thanks for the heads-up @waffles.The MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log is an important part of Edge Updates diagnostic flow, so we'd like to keep logging to it if there ia a viable way of securing this log file<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the heads-up @waffles.The MicrosoftEdgeUpdate.log is an important part of Edge Updates diagnostic flow, so we'd like to keep logging to it if there ia a viable way of securing this log file<!----></span><br>The thread mentions two different solutions to secure this file:<span class="line"><!---->The thread mentions two different solutions to secure this file:<!----></span><br>- oplocks <span class="line"><!---->- oplocks <!----></span><br>- DACLs<span class="line"><!---->- DACLs<!----></span><br>Can anyone elaborate on these approaches (e.g. how to use oplocks when MicoroftEdgeUpdate.log isn't running?, what DACL settings would secure this file?). On the surface, the DACL approach seems the most straightforward. And looking at the logging code [<span class="line"><!---->Can anyone elaborate on these approaches (e.g. how to use oplocks when MicoroftEdgeUpdate.log isn't running?, what DACL settings would secure this file?). On the surface, the DACL approach seems the most straightforward. And looking at the logging code [<!----></span>https://github.com/google/omaha/blob/main/omaha/base/logging.cc<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://github.com/google/omaha/blob/main/omaha/base/logging.cc"><!---->https://github.com/google/omaha/blob/main/omaha/base/logging.cc<!----></a>],<span class="line"><!---->],<!----></span> it seems the core issue is this:<span class="line"><!----> it seems the core issue is this:<!----></span><br><br>  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<span class="line"><!---->  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<!----></span><br>  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<span class="line"><!---->  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<!----></span><br>  CDacl dacl;<span class="line"><!---->  CDacl dacl;<!----></span><br>  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<!----></span><br>    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<span class="line"><!---->    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br><br>@sorin/@waffles -- is there a functionality reason that this is explicitly allowing all uses to *Write* and *Delete* the file? In most (all?) use cases systems install Omaha should be running as SYSTEM. And the file itself is size-limited, so I don't think disallow Delete would be a problem for end-users (e.g. to reclaim space).<span class="line"><!---->@sorin/@waffles -- is there a functionality reason that this is explicitly allowing all uses to *Write* and *Delete* the file? In most (all?) use cases systems install Omaha should be running as SYSTEM. And the file itself is size-limited, so I don't think disallow Delete would be a problem for end-users (e.g. to reclaim space).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        > Omaha can run as SYSTEM, or at medium for user installs as well as at medium for the system case before elevating. <span class="line"><!---->&gt; Omaha can run as SYSTEM, or at medium for user installs as well as at medium for the system case before elevating. <!----></span><br>Logging before we elevate is not a core scenario as we can do without (Edge is mostly in-box and always elevated). And on user installs log file is not created as SYSTEM (nor under C:\ProgramData) so I don't believe those uses are vulnerable.  <span class="line"><!---->Logging before we elevate is not a core scenario as we can do without (Edge is mostly in-box and always elevated). And on user installs log file is not created as SYSTEM (nor under C:\ProgramData) so I don't believe those uses are vulnerable.  <!----></span><br><br>So unless there isn't another reason why the "  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file." code is in place, I'm tempted to just remove that, assume the logging code won't blow up if it can't write.  Looks like I'll also need to fix up FileLogWriter::Initialize() to handle failures from CreateLoggingFile(), but not much else I can see.<span class="line"><!---->So unless there isn't another reason why the "  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file." code is in place, I'm tempted to just remove that, assume the logging code won't blow up if it can't write.  Looks like I'll also need to fix up FileLogWriter::Initialize() to handle failures from CreateLoggingFile(), but not much else I can see.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Confirmed.<span class="line"><!---->Confirmed.<!----></span><br><br>We are starting the flight of a new Edge Update series -- 1.3.165.xx -- that doesn't give all users read/write/delete access to the log file. This may lead to minor data loss  (e.g. logging of some EdgeUpdate activities) in some side cases, but we are willing to live with that to avoid this exploit.<span class="line"><!---->We are starting the flight of a new Edge Update series -- 1.3.165.xx -- that doesn't give all users read/write/delete access to the log file. This may lead to minor data loss  (e.g. logging of some EdgeUpdate activities) in some side cases, but we are willing to live with that to avoid this exploit.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        Updating as external dependency as seems to be an issue specific to Edge. <span class="line"><!---->Updating as external dependency as seems to be an issue specific to Edge. <!----></span><br><br>To the reporter, thank you for this report; however, this issue does not appear to be impact Chrome and, unfortunately, would not be eligible for the Chrome VRP. [1]<span class="line"><!---->To the reporter, thank you for this report; however, this issue does not appear to be impact Chrome and, unfortunately, would not be eligible for the Chrome VRP. [1]<!----></span><br>Only issues that manifest in/impact Chrome are eligible for the Chrome VRP and to result in points for the Google Bughunters and Chrome VRP leaderboards. <span class="line"><!---->Only issues that manifest in/impact Chrome are eligible for the Chrome VRP and to result in points for the Google Bughunters and Chrome VRP leaderboards. <!----></span><br><br>Have you reported these issues directly to the MSRC and/or have they created issues in their program for you to be acknowledged and receive a bounty from the Microsoft/Edge Bug Bounty program? I'm presuming you have done this already and you'll be acknowledged via MSRC and be eligible for consideration though their bug bounty. <span class="line"><!---->Have you reported these issues directly to the MSRC and/or have they created issues in their program for you to be acknowledged and receive a bounty from the Microsoft/Edge Bug Bounty program?         This has been fixed in Edge Update 1.3.165.21 (and later).<span class="line"><!---->This has been fixed in Edge Update 1.3.165.21 (and later).<!----></span><br><br>The code in FileLogWriter::CreateLoggingFile() [base\logging.cc] was changed to disable this code block:<span class="line"><!---->The code in FileLogWriter::CreateLoggingFile() [base\logging.cc] was changed to disable this code block:<!----></span><br><br>#if 0 // REMOVED due to Security issue: <span class="line"><!---->#if 0 // REMOVED due to Security issue: <!----></span>https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1332924#c8<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1332924#c8"><!---->https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1332924#c8<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><br>      // This will not allow for other non-elevated Omahas to write, but that<span class="line"><!---->      // This will not allow for other non-elevated Omahas to write, but that<!----></span><br>      // is in the minority case now that Edge is in-box.<span class="line"><!---->      // is in the minority case now that Edge is in-box.<!----></span><br>  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<span class="line"><!---->  // Allow users to read, write, and delete the log file.<!----></span><br>  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<span class="line"><!---->  ACCESS_MASK mask = GENERIC_READ | GENERIC_WRITE | DELETE;<!----></span><br>  CDacl dacl;<span class="line"><!---->  CDacl dacl;<!----></span><br>  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<span class="line"><!---->  if (dacl.AddAllowedAce(ATL::Sids::Users(), mask)) {<!----></span><br>    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<span class="line"><!---->    AtlSetDacl(file_name_, SE_FILE_OBJECT, dacl);<!----></span><br>  }<span class="line"><!---->  }<!----></span><br>#endif // 0<span class="line"><!---->#endif // 0<!----></span><br><br>This was a different mitigation than upstream--which disabled most logging--since logs are still important diagnostic tools for Edge Update and most installs are system-based (i.e., elevated).<span class="line"><!---->This was a different mitigation than upstream--which disabled most logging--since logs are still important diagnostic tools for Edge Update and most installs are system-based (i.e., elevated).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Hello, automated public disclosure of security bugs is 14 weeks after fix. Since this issue was just fixed on 6 September, that would not occur until 13 December. <span class="line"><!---->Hello, automated public disclosure of security bugs is 14 weeks after fix. Since this issue was just fixed on 6 September, that would not occur until 13 December. <!----></span><br>We have no insight into the mentioned email, but the MSRC team said they are working on this, so we would appreciate continued patience while Microsoft works to resolve this issue. <span class="line"><!---->We have no insight into the mentioned email, but the MSRC team said they are working on this, so we would appreciate continued patience while Microsoft works to resolve this issue. <!----></span><br>This is your finding, so of course, you are free to publicly disclose on your own, but I believe you would be ineligible for MSRC/Edge's bug bounty program and forfeit any reward from them. In the interim, in keeping with our Chromium public disclosure policies, this bug will remain restricted until the 13 December public disclosure date.<span class="line"><!---->This is your finding, so of course, you are free to publicly disclose on your own, but I believe you would be ineligible for MSRC/Edge's bug bounty program and forfeit any reward from them. In the interim, in keeping with our Chromium public disclosure policies, this bug will remain restricted until the 13 December public disclosure date.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
